questions.text: A 26-year-old male presents with back ache, morning stiffness and reddening of eyes. X-ray of the patient is given below. Identify the diagnosis of this patient: (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ankylosing spondylitis

 

ANKYLOSING SPONDYLITIS

 

  • Also known as Marie-Strumpell or Bechterew’s disease.
  • It is a seronegative spondyloarthropathy.
  • It is a chronic inflammatory disease affecting the spine and sacroiliac joints.
  • It also have a variable involvement of root joints (shoulder and hip) and peripheral joints.
  • The involvement is an enthesopathy.
  • HLA B27 is positive in 90% patients.
  • Sacroiliitis is the earliest manifestation with features of both enthesitis and synovitis.
  • Joints Involved:
    • Primarily affects axial skeleton.
    • The disease usually begins in the sacroiliac joints and usually extends upwards to involve the lumbar, thoracic, and often cervical spine.
    • Hip joint is the most commonly affected peripheral joint.
    • Rarely, knee and ankle are also involved.
       
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • It is most commonly seen in young males aged 15-25 years.
    • Most common symptom is dull backache, insidious in onset, felt deep in lower lumbar or gluteal region, associated with low back morning stiffness of up to few hour duration that improves with activity and returns following period of inactivity.
    • Question mark (?) posture is due to hyperkyphosis of thoracic spine and loss of lumbar lordosis.
    • Cervical spine involvement is usually late and show forward stooping and loss of extension and rotation.
    • Most serious complication of spinal disease is spinal fracture with even minor trauma.
    • Anterior uveitis: Most common (30%) extra-articular manifestation.
    • Cataract and secondary glaucoma are common sequela.
    • Up to 60% of patients have inflammation of colon or ileum (mostly asymptomatic, only 5-10% develop IBD), 3rd degree heart block, cardiac dysfunction (Aortic incompetence), restrictive lung disease. IgA nephropathy, prostatitis and retroperitoneal fibrosis are other manifestations and may shorten life span.
       
  • Diagnostic criteria – Modified New York Criterion:
    • Essential criteria is definite radiographic sacroiliitis
    • Supporting criteria: one of these 3
      • Inflammatory back pain if 4/5 are present 
        1. Pain > 3 months
        2. < 40 years of age
        3. Insidious onset
        4. Improves with exercise
        5. Present at night
           
      • Limited chest expansion
      • Limited lumbar spine motion in both sagittal and frontal plane (schober test/modified schober test)
         
  • Spine Radiograph Findings:
    • Haziness of sacroiliac (SI) joint margins is the earliest change.

 

 

Sacroiliitis

 

  • Later on, SI joint show irregular subchondral erosions, sclerotic articular margins, joint space widening and eventually bony ankylosis.
  • Calcification of supraspinous and interspinous ligaments (Dagger sign) and that of sacroiliac and sacro-tuberous ligament.

 

 

Dagger sign (ossification along supraspinous & interspinous ligaments)

 

  • Enthesopathy: Calcification at the attachment of muscles, tendons and ligaments.
  • Trolley/tram track sign: Three linear radiopaque lines due to ligament calcification.
  • Squaring of vertebra, loss of lumbar lordosis and syndesmophytes are seen. Bamboo spine appearance is due to syndesmophytes.

 

 

A. Trolley track sign (ossification along supraspinous ligaments and facet joints;

B. Bamboo spine

 

  • MRI is the most sensitive examination for sacroiliitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rheumatoid arthritis. In rheumatoid arthritis, upper cervical spine & hip joint are less commonly involved. There is atlantoaxial joint subluxation when cervical spine is involved. Lumbar spine is usually spared. The chronic inflammatory synovitis in the cervical spine results in severity that progresses to bone erosion and ligamentous laxity, leading to late spinal instability. The most common radiological presentations of spinal involvement in RA are: atlantoaxial subluxation, cranial settling (also known as basilar impression, atlantoaxial impaction or superior migration of the odontoid, the most severe form of spinal instability in RA), subaxial subluxation or a combination of them.

 

 

Option B. Psoriatic arthritis. In the involvement of spine & pelvis in psoriatic arthritis, the patient experiences extreme back/neck pain, stiffness in back/neck that improves on moving around. The stiffness worsens by a period of rest. There is difficulty in bending or moving the back. The patient also complaints of fatigue. The x-ray shows asymmetric paravertebral ossification, thicker & larger syndesmophytes than ankylosing spondylitis. Occasionally, there are incomplete non-marginal syndesmophytes similar to AS.

 

 

Option D. Paget’s disease. It is characterized by excessive disorganized bone turnover, that encompasses excessive osteoclastic activity initially followed by disorganized excessive new bone formation. Osteoclast appears larger and irregular whereas osteoblast are relatively normal. Etiology is genetic infection by paramyxovirus (measles and respiratory syncytial virus). There is increased bone resorption accompanied by accelerated bone formation. Most people are asymptomatic. The sites most commonly involved are pelvis, tibia, followed by skull, spine, clavicle and femur. Affects men > 50 years more commonly. Pain is most common presenting symptom. The spine is the second most commonly affected site (53%), after the pelvis (70%). The lumbar spine and more commonly the L4 and L5 levels are the most frequently involved sites. Involvement of the atlanto-axial region is very rare. The vertebral body is almost always involved with a portion of the neural arch. The radiological appearance is characterised by an increase in the antero-posterior and lateral vertebral dimensions. The height of the vertebra is unchanged. The vertebral end-plates are subchondral condensations of trabecular bone and do not represent true bony cortex, i.e. there is no periosteum/endosteum interface at the caudal/cranial aspect of a normal vertebra. The “early” radiographic appearance of vertebral body is thickening and hypertrophy of the trabecular bone, parallel to the end plates. Progression of the sclerotic phase in the spine leads to “ivory vertebra”, due to an increase in the density of the vertebral body.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The described symptoms of back ache, morning stiffness and reddening of eyes, along with the bamboo spine appearance in the spine x-ray are diagnostic of ankylosing spondylitis.

choices.text: Rinne’s test positive , Weber’s test lateralized to left ear
Rinne’s test positive , Weber’s test lateralized to right ear
Rinne’s test negative , Weber’s test lateralized to left ear
Rinne’s test negative , Weber’s test lateralized to right ear

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with bilateral hearing loss with worsened right ear hearing loss. On examination, the doctor diagnose Otosclerosis and recommends stapedectomy as a final resort to the problem. What would be the findings of tuning fork tests based on which the doctor has recommended stapedectomy? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Rinne’s test negative, Weber’s test lateralized to right ear

 

  • Rinne’s test negative: Typical of otosclerosis, indicating conductive hearing loss where BC > AC.
  • Weber’s test lateralized to right ear: Indicates that the sound is heard better in the ear with more conductive loss, which matches otosclerosis more severely affecting the right ear.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rinne’s test positive, Weber’s test lateralized to left ear:

 

  • Rinne’s test positive: Indicates that air conduction (AC) is better than bone conduction (BC), which is a normal finding and typically not expected in conductive hearing loss like otosclerosis.
  • Weber’s test lateralized to left ear: In a case of unilateral or asymmetric hearing loss, Weber's test lateralizes to the better hearing ear in sensorineural hearing loss and to the poorer ear in conductive hearing loss. This pattern does not fit otosclerosis affecting the right ear more severely.

 

Option B. Rinne’s test positive, Weber’s test lateralized to right ear:

 

  • Rinne’s test positive: Again, indicates normal AC > BC, not typical for otosclerosis.
  • Weber’s test lateralized to right ear: Would suggest either a sensorineural hearing loss on the left ear or less likely conductive loss on the right, which doesn’t match typical otosclerosis findings.

 

Option C. Rinne’s test negative, Weber’s test lateralized to left ear:

 

  • Rinne’s test negative: Indicates that BC > AC, suggesting conductive hearing loss, typical of otosclerosis.
  • Weber’s test lateralized to left ear: Would imply the left ear is either better or has conductive loss, not aligning with greater hearing loss in the right ear due to otosclerosis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The combination of a negative Rinne test and Weber test lateralizing to the ear with more hearing loss is indicative of conductive hearing loss in that ear. In otosclerosis, the ossification of the stapes leads to mechanical dysfunction, preventing effective sound transmission, hence a stapedectomy might be recommended to mechanically bypass the ossified stapes and improve hearing.

questions.text: A group organized a mass gathering on handwashing awareness. Arrange the steps in the correct chronological sequence: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Awareness – Interest – Evaluation – Trial – Adoption 

 

When motivating a group to adopt a new practice like handwashing, there is a specific sequence of steps that follows the AITA principle:

 

  • Awareness - First, people need to be made aware that handwashing exists and is beneficial for health
  • Interest - Once aware, they develop interest in understanding how it benefits their health
  • Evaluation - They evaluate the information they've learned about handwashing
  • Trial - They try the practice of handwashing
  • Adoption - If found useful, they incorporate handwashing into their daily routine

 

Educational Objective: 

 

 The correct sequence for behavior change adoption in health education:

 

 Awareness → Interest → Evaluation → Trial → Adoption (AITA)

questions.text: World's only licensed malaria vaccine - MOSQUIRIX is prepared from which component of Plasmodium falciparum? [NEET PG 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Circumsporozoite protein

 

  • The RTS,S vaccine (also known as MOSQUIRIX) targets the circumsporozoite protein (CSP) of the malaria parasite. MOSQUIRIX is described as "MOSQUIRIX (CSPpf + EP HBsAg) – Recombinant protein based vaccine – 1st licensed malaria vaccine – Efficacy – 26-50%". 

  • This vaccine combines the circumsporozoite protein of Plasmodium falciparum (CSPpf) with the hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) as a carrier protein.

     

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gametocytic protein: Malaria vaccines don't target gametocytic proteins. The RTS,S vaccine specifically targets the circumsporozoite protein found on the surface of sporozoites (the pre-erythrocytic stage), not the gametocyte stage.

 

Option B. Polysaccharide sheath: No polysaccharide sheath component is targeted by the RTS,S vaccine. Malaria vaccines including RTS,S primarily target protein components, not polysaccharide structures.

 

Option D. Lipoprotein envelope: RTS,S does not target any lipoprotein envelope. The vaccine specifically targets the circumsporozoite protein as indicated in the description of MOSQUIRIX.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The RTS,S (MOSQUIRIX) malaria vaccine is a recombinant protein-based vaccine that targets the circumsporozoite protein of Plasmodium falciparum, giving it partial efficacy (26-50%) as the first licensed malaria vaccine.

questions.text: The histology of a 12-month-old boy with an abdominal tumor shows multiple elements, including blastemal, stromal, and epithelial tissues. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Wilms tumor

 

Wilms tumor (nephroblastoma) is a malignant renal tumor that typically occurs in children between 2-5 years of age. The characteristic histological pattern described in the question is the classic "triphasic pattern" of Wilms tumor consisting of blastemal, epithelial, and stromal components. This is often referred to by the mnemonic "BEST" (Blastemal, Epithelial, STromal). The tumor presents as an abdominal mass, which is the earliest and most common presentation, along with potential symptoms of fever and hematuria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ganglioneuroma - This is a benign tumor of the sympathetic nervous system composed of mature ganglion cells and Schwann cells. It lacks the triphasic pattern with blastemal elements seen in Wilms tumor.

 

Option B. Neuroblastoma - While this is also a common pediatric malignancy, neuroblastoma is derived from neural crest cells and consists of small round blue cells with rosette formation. It doesn't contain the triphasic pattern described.

 

Option C. Teratocarcinoma - This is a mixed germ cell tumor containing teratomatous elements and embryonal carcinoma. While it may have multiple tissue types, it typically occurs in the gonads (testis) rather than the kidney in children.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Wilms tumor is characterized histologically by a triphasic pattern of blastemal, epithelial, and stromal components (BEST), and is the most common primary renal malignancy in children, typically presenting as an abdominal mass in children aged 2-5 years.

questions.text: Which of the following helps in bacterial adhesion? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fimbriae

 

Fimbriae help in bacterial adhesion.

 

Fimbriae, also called pili are hair-like surface appendage that projects from the cell surface as straight filaments. Fimbriae are classified based on the function as ordinary pili and sex pili.

 

Functions of pili:

 

  • Bacterial adhesion of symbiotic and pathogenic bacteria to host cells using adhesins.
  • Resistance to phagocytosis.
  • Antigenic pilin proteins are responsible for the immune response.
  • Twitching motility to bacteria.
  • Bacterial conjugation through sex pili, which transfer of genetic material occurs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cytoplasmic membrane: While important for many cellular functions, the cytoplasmic membrane itself is not typically involved in adhesion.

 

Option B. Mesosomes: These are folded invaginations in the bacterial membrane thought to be artifacts of cell preparation and not involved in adhesion.

 

Option D. Lipopolysaccharides (LPS): Found in the outer membrane of Gram-negative bacteria, LPS can play a role in interactions with the host immune system but are not primarily responsible for adhesion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fimbriae are essential bacterial structures for adhesion, enabling bacteria to attach to host cells and surfaces, crucial for initiating infections and forming biofilms. This key role makes them important targets for strategies to prevent and treat bacterial infections.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient arrives at the hospital emergency department presenting with gastrointestinal distress. The patient complains of severe abdominal pain, frequent vomiting, and watery diarrhea. During the physical examination, the medical team observes that the patient's stools emit an unusual faint glow. The patient appears disoriented and fatigued. The medical history reveals that the patient attended a local festival the previous day and consumed various food items there. The following exposures might be contributing to which substance toxication? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Phosphorus

 

The vomitus and stools turn luminescent in acute phosphorus poisoning.

 

The stools also release mild fumes and this is called ‘smoky stool syndrome’.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mercury: Symptoms: Tremors, memory loss, gingivitis, and gastrointestinal distress.

 

Option B. Cadmium: Symptoms: Nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, and renal damage.

 

Option D. Calcium: Symptoms: Hypercalcemia, muscle weakness, confusion, and abdominal pain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Comparison of Poisoning Types:

questions.text: In a standard normal distribution, what percentage of data values fall within one standard deviation of the mean? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 68%

 

In a standard normal distribution, the data is symmetrically distributed around the mean, forming a bell-shaped curve known as the Gaussian distribution. This distribution is characterized by the following properties:

 

  • The mean, median, and mode of the distribution are equal and located at the center of the curve.
  • The curve is bilaterally symmetrical, meaning if a perpendicular line is drawn from the top of the curve, it divides the graph into two equal halves.

 

One of the key features of a standard normal distribution is that it follows the empirical rule, which states:

 

 

Therefore, the percentage of data values that fall within one standard deviation of the mean in a standard normal distribution is approximately 68%.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a standard normal distribution, 68% of the data values fall within one standard deviation of the mean.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male has been diagnosed with achalasia cardia through esophageal manometry. The manometry results reveal simultaneous, high-pressure contractions in the distal esophagus, along with spasmodic contractions. What type of achalasia does this patient's presentation correspond among the provided options?(NEET PG  2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Type III

 

The classification of achalasia into types I, II, and III is based on the Chicago Classification. This system uses high-resolution manometry to categorize esophageal motility disorders.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Type III achalasia, also known as spastic achalasia, involves spastic contractions in the distal esophagus and failure of the lower esophageal sphincter to relax. This type is the least common and often requires more aggressive therapy.

questions.text: Which section of IPC defines McNaughten's rule? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Section 84 of IPC

 

Section 84 IPC: Act of a person of unsound mind

 

Nothing is an offence which is done by a person who, at the time of doing it, by reason of unsoundness of mind, is incapable of knowing the nature of the act, or that he is doing what is either wrong or contrary to law.

 

Other Options

 

Other 3 options are not related to the McNaughten Rule

 

Educational Objective

 

Section 84 of IPC defines the act of a person of unsound mind and is derived from the McNaughten Rule, providing a legal defense for individuals who commit crimes due to their mental incapacity.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman presented at 7 weeks of gestation, unwilling to continue the pregnancy. What are the drugs used for medical termination of pregnancy in this patient? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Misoprostol and Mifepristone

 

Explanation:

 

  • Misoprostol and Mifepristone:
    • The drugs used for medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) in this patient presenting at 7 weeks of gestation are misoprostol and mifepristone.
    • Mifepristone 200 mg is administered orally on day 1. It acts as an antiprogestogen, blocking the effects of progesterone, which is essential to maintain pregnancy.
    • Misoprostol is given 24-48 hours after mifepristone. Misoprostol, a prostaglandin E1 analog, induces uterine contractions to expel the pregnancy tissue.
    • Clinical confirmation of MTP is done on day 14 through clinical examination and/or ultrasonography to ensure the complete expulsion of the products of conception.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Misoprostol and Medroxyprogesterone: Medroxyprogesterone is a synthetic progestin used in contraception and hormone replacement therapy but is not used in medical termination of pregnancy.

 

Option C. Mifepristone and Methotrexate: Methotrexate is a folate antagonist that can be used in combination with misoprostol for medical termination of pregnancy, especially in early gestations, but it is not the standard regimen compared to mifepristone and misoprostol.

 

Option D. Mifepristone and Medroxyprogesterone: Medroxyprogesterone is not used in medical termination of pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For medical termination of pregnancy at 7 weeks of gestation, the recommended drugs are mifepristone followed by misoprostol.

 

 

Ref: https://main.mohfw.gov.in/acts-rules-and-standards-health-sector/acts/mtp-rules

questions.text: Identify the structures shown in the images: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Corpora amylacea

 

The image shows corpora amylacea, which are spherical laminated hyaline structures commonly seen in elderly males in the prostate and represent a normal aging change. These are glycoprotein deposits that appear as round, concentrically laminated, eosinophilic (pink) structures with a glassy appearance. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Corpus callosum: Incorrect. Corpus callosum is a broad band of nerve fibers that connects the two cerebral hemispheres in the brain. It would appear as white matter tracts in histological sections of brain tissue, not as concentric laminated structures seen in the image.

 

Option B. Psammoma body: Incorrect. Psammoma bodies are concentrically laminated calcifications that appear as round, basophilic (blue) structures, typically found in certain neoplasms like meningiomas, papillary thyroid carcinoma, and serous cystadenocarcinoma of the ovary. 

 

 

Option C. Corpus luteum: Incorrect. Corpus luteum is a temporary endocrine structure formed in the ovary after ovulation. Histologically, it would appear as a follicular structure with luteinized granulosa cells having abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The histological appearance of corpora amylacea, which are eosinophilic, concentrically laminated glycoprotein deposits that commonly occur in the prostate gland of elderly males as part of the normal aging process.

questions.text: The Gardasil vaccine provides protection against which types of human papillomavirus (HPV)? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) HPV types 6, 11, 16, and 18

 

Gardasil is a quadrivalent HPV vaccine that protects against four HPV types: 6, 11, 16, and 18. HPV types 16 and 18 are high-risk types associated with cervical cancer, while types 6 and 11 cause genital warts. This quadrivalent formulation provides protection against both cancer-causing strains and those responsible for genital warts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: HPV types 16 and 18: This describes Cervarix, which is a bivalent vaccine covering only the high-risk oncogenic HPV types 16 and 18. Gardasil provides broader coverage by including types 6 and 11 as well.

 

Option B: HPV types 6 and 11: This is incomplete as it only includes the HPV types associated with genital warts (low-risk types). Gardasil also includes the high-risk oncogenic types 16 and 18.

 

Option D: HPV types 16, 18, 31, and 33: This combination does not match any currently available HPV vaccine. The newer Gardasil 9 is a nonavalent vaccine that includes types 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, and 58, but the original Gardasil is quadrivalent (6, 11, 16, 18).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gardasil is a quadrivalent HPV vaccine that protects against both low-risk HPV types (6, 11) that cause genital warts and high-risk HPV types (16, 18) that cause cervical cancer, providing broader protection than bivalent vaccines.

questions.text: Basket weave appearance of Glomerular Basement Membrane on Electron Microscopy is seen in: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Alport syndrome

 

Explanation: 

 

Alport syndrome is characterized by a distinctive "basket weave appearance" of the glomerular basement membrane on electron microscopy. This morphological finding is due to a defect in the α5 chain of type IV collagen, which is the primary component of the GBM. In Alport syndrome, the basement membrane shows characteristic irregular thickening, lamellation of the lamina densa, and pronounced splitting, creating the distinctive basketweave pattern that is diagnostic for this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acute Post Streptococcal GN - This condition typically shows subepithelial humps or deposits on electron microscopy, not basket weave appearance. These electron-dense "humps" are immune complexes nestled against the GBM, typically in subepithelial locations.

 

Option C. Polyarteritis nodosa - This is a systemic vasculitis affecting medium-sized arteries, not primarily a glomerular disease. It does not show basket weave appearance of the GBM on electron microscopy.

 

Option D. Giant cell arteritis - This is a vasculitis affecting large and medium-sized arteries, particularly cranial branches of arteries originating from the aortic arch. It does not affect glomerular basement membranes and thus would not show basket weave appearance.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The basket weave appearance on electron microscopy—characterized by alternating thickening of the glomerular basement membrane with lamellation and splitting—is a pathognomonic finding in Alport syndrome, representing the ultrastructural manifestation of the underlying genetic defect in type IV collagen.

questions.text: A patient presented in the ER with hypotension. On auscultation, dullness of heart sound and dilated neck veins was diagnosed, along with cardiac tamponade. Which of the following JVP findings is typically associated with cardiac tamponade? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Absent y descent

 

Explanation:


In cardiac tamponade, there is an accumulation of fluid in the pericardial sac, which impairs the filling of the heart chambers, particularly during diastole. This results in the characteristic absence of the y descent in the jugular venous pressure (JVP) waveform.

 

The y descent normally represents the rapid filling phase of the right atrium and right ventricle.

 

In cardiac tamponade, this filling is restricted, leading to a blunted or absent y descent.

 

Mnemonic "No ThankYou"  → No/ Absence of the Y descent in cardiac Tamponade.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Prominent x descent: This is typically seen in conditions with increased atrial relaxation and tricuspid regurgitation, but not in cardiac tamponade.

 

Option B. Cannon a wave: This is associated with conditions involving atrioventricular dissociation, such as complete heart block, where atrial contractions occur against a closed tricuspid valve.

 

Option D. Absent a wave: The a wave is absent in atrial fibrillation, where there is no coordinated atrial contraction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cardiac tamponade, the characteristic JVP finding is the absence of the y descent.

questions.text: 2,3 BPG binds with which of the following? (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Globin part of hemoglobin

 

Option B. Globin part of hemoglobin: 2,3-BPG binds to the beta chains of the globin part of hemoglobin. This binding reduces hemoglobin's affinity for oxygen, facilitating oxygen release to tissues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Globin part of myoglobin: 2,3-BPG does not bind to myoglobin. Myoglobin, primarily found in muscle tissue, has a higher affinity for oxygen and does not interact with 2,3-BPG.

 

Option C. Heme part of myoglobin: The heme part of myoglobin binds to oxygen directly; 2,3-BPG does not bind to this site or affect myoglobin's oxygen affinity.

 

Option D. Heme part of hemoglobin: While the heme part of hemoglobin is the site for oxygen binding, 2,3-BPG does not bind here. It binds at a separate site on the globin chains to modulate oxygen affinity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

2,3-BPG binds to the beta chains of the globin part of hemoglobin, reducing its affinity for oxygen and facilitating the release of oxygen to tissues. This interaction is crucial for efficient oxygen delivery in response to tissue demands.

questions.text: Which patient category is classified as "green" according to the triage system? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ambulatory patients

 

  • The triage system is a method used by medical professionals to prioritize patient care based on the severity of their condition.
  • The triage system typically uses a color-coding scheme to classify patients into different categories.
  • These categories help in quickly identifying which patients need immediate attention and which can wait.
  • Green category: Patients classified under the "green" category are those with non-urgent medical needs. These patients are ambulatory, meaning they can walk and move around on their own. Their injuries or illnesses are minor and do not require immediate medical intervention. These patients can safely wait for medical attention without any significant risk to their health.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Medium risk patients: Patients classified as medium risk typically fall under the "yellow" category in the triage system. These patients have urgent medical needs but their condition is not immediately life-threatening. They need medical attention soon but can wait for a short period without significant risk to their health.

 

Option C. High risk patients: High risk patients are usually classified under the "red" category. These patients need immediate life-saving interventions due to critical conditions such as severe bleeding, difficulty breathing, or major trauma. Delaying treatment for these patients could result in severe complications or death.

 

Option D. Dead patients: Patients classified as dead or who have injuries that are beyond medical intervention fall under the "black" category. These patients are either deceased or have injuries that are so severe that survival is not expected even with medical intervention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The "green" category in the triage system is used for ambulatory patients with minor injuries or illnesses.
  • These patients do not require immediate medical attention and can safely wait for treatment.

questions.text: What kind of symptoms does the term affective flattening imply? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Negative symptoms

 

Affective flattening is a negative symptom characterized by:

 

  • Lack of emotional response/emotional blunting
  • Decreased expression of emotions
    • It is one of the 6 A's of negative symptoms (others being Avolition, Apathy, Anhedonia, Asociality, and Alogia). 
    • Negative symptoms represent a reduction or loss of normal functions, unlike positive symptoms which represent an excess or distortion of normal functions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Positive symptoms: Incorrect because positive symptoms represent excess or distortion of normal functions (like hallucinations and delusions). Affective flattening represents a reduction in emotional expression, making it a negative symptom.

 

Option C. Affect symptoms: Incorrect because while affective flattening involves affect, it's specifically categorized as a negative symptom due to its nature of representing a reduction in normal emotional expression.

 

Option D. Cognitive symptoms: Incorrect because cognitive symptoms relate to thinking and mental processes like attention, memory, and executive function. Affective flattening is related to emotional expression, not cognitive function.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which among the following monitors is most commonly used to monitor the depth of anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bispectral index

 

  • The bispectral index (BIS) is the most commonly used method to monitor the depth of anesthesia and determine the level of consciousness under anesthesia.
  • BIS is derived from the EEG (electroencephalogram) and shows the cerebral drug effect of an anesthetic drug.
  • BIS values range from 0-100, where lower values indicate deeper anesthesia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. EEG: While EEG is the basis for BIS, it is not typically used directly in clinical practice to monitor anesthesia depth due to its complexity.

 

Option B. Provoked lower esophageal contractility: This is not a standard or common method for monitoring the depth of anesthesia.

 

Option C. Entropy: Entropy monitoring is another EEG-based technique used to assess the depth of anesthesia. However, it is less commonly used compared to BIS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The bispectral index (BIS) is the most commonly used monitor to assess the depth of anesthesia, providing an EEG-derived measure of the cerebral effects of anesthetic drugs.

questions.text: What method is most effective for visually representing the fluctuations in disease occurrence within a given area over time? [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Line graph

 

Line graphs or line diagrams are the best way to plot the changes in the incidence of a disease in a given area over time (TREND of any event).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Histogram: Is graphical presentation for ‘continuous quantitative data’

 

  • Continuous groups are marked on x-axis (abscissa) while frequencies are marked on y-axis (ordinate).

 

 

Option C. Ogive:  Is graph of cumulative relative frequency distribution

 

 

Option D. Stem and leaf plot:  Represents quantitative data in graphical format which helps us visualize the shape of distribution. We are able to represent frequencies for different classes of values.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Line graphs are the most effective method for visually representing the fluctuations in disease occurrence over time, making them ideal for identifying and analyzing trends in epidemiological data.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman is diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis. What associated complication is shown in the image? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Scleromalacia perforans

 

  • Scleromalacia perforans is a complication of rheumatoid arthritis shown in the image.
  • It is a type of necrotizing scleritis without inflammation. Typically occurs in elderly females with long-standing rheumatoid arthritis.
  • It is characterized by the development of yellowish patch of melting sclera. The sclera melts due to obliteration of blood supply.
  • Episclera and conjunctiva often completely separate from the surrounding normal sclera.
  • Sequestrum of sclera becomes dead white in colour.
  • Eventually, sequestrum absorbs leaving behind a large punched-out area of thin sclera through which the uveal tissue shines. Spontaneous perforation is extremely rare.
  • Clinical features include pain, photophobia, and lacrimation. The affected eye appears red.
  • Medical management includes steroids and immunosuppressants.
  • In severe cases, surgical treatment by scleral patch graft may be done.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. ﻿﻿﻿Ciliary staphyloma:

  • It is used to describe the bulge of an area of weak sclera lined by the ciliary body.
  • Common causes include scleritis, developmental glaucoma, and end-stage primary or secondary glaucoma.
  • Another cause includes thinning of the sclera, secondary to perforating injury.

 

 

Option C. Coloboma:

  • It is a congenital anomaly, that develops due to a defect in the closure of the embryonic cleft.
  • It is characterized by poorly developed or deficient uveal tissue. The lens, choroid, and retina may also be involved.
  • The image below shows coloboma of the right eyelid.

 

 

Option D. Malignant melanoma:

  • It is usually seen in elderly patients.
  • If it involves the conjunctiva, it appears as a mass near the limbus. It can be pigmented or non-pigmented.
  • The choroid, iris, ciliary body, and eyelids can also develop the tumour.
  • The image below shows malignant melanoma of the conjunctiva.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Scleromalacia perforans is a severe ocular complication of long-standing rheumatoid arthritis characterized by a melting patch of sclera with exposure of underlying uveal tissue, typically managed with steroids, immunosuppressants, and potentially surgical intervention.

questions.text: Nitric oxide is synthesized from: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) L-Arginine

 

Nitric oxide (NO) is synthesized from L-arginine through the action of enzymes known as nitric oxide synthases (NOS). There are different forms of NOS enzymes, including endothelial NOS (eNOS) and neuronal NOS (nNOS), which are involved in the production of NO in various tissues and cells. L-arginine serves as the precursor for NO synthesis in the body.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. L-Citrulline: While L-citrulline is related to the nitric oxide pathway, it is not the direct precursor for NO synthesis. Instead, L-citrulline can be converted back into L-arginine in the body, and then L-arginine is used for NO production. This makes L-citrulline indirectly involved in the regulation of NO levels.

 

Option C. Glycine: Glycine is not directly involved in the synthesis of nitric oxide. It is an amino acid with its own metabolic functions in the body but is not a precursor for NO.

 

Option D. Lysine: Lysine is also not directly involved in the synthesis of nitric oxide. It is an essential amino acid with its own roles in protein synthesis and metabolism but is not part of the NO synthesis pathway.

 

Educational Objective:

 

NO (nitric oxide) is synthesized from arginine by enzyme NOS (Nitric oxide synthase) in the endothelial cells.

 

 

NO is also called as Endothelium Derived Relaxing Factor (EDRF). It causes vasodilatation and acts through the formation of secondary messenger cGMP.

 

NOS (multienzyme complex)

 

  • There are three isoforms of NOS 
    1. iNOS- inducible
    2. nNOS - neuronal
    3. eNOS- endothelial

questions.text: All are features of Conn's syndrome except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Metabolic acidosis

 

Explanation:

 

Conn's syndrome, also known as primary hyperaldosteronism, is characterized by an excess production of aldosterone, usually due to an adrenal adenoma.

 

The typical features of Conn's syndrome include:

 

  • Hypertension: Due to increased sodium and water retention.
  • Hypokalemia: Caused by increased potassium excretion.
  • Metabolic alkalosis: Due to increased hydrogen ion excretion and bicarbonate retention.

 

Metabolic acidosis is not a feature of Conn's syndrome. It is more commonly associated with conditions where there is a deficiency of aldosterone, such as adrenal insufficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metabolic alkalosis: Correctly associated with Conn's syndrome due to aldosterone's effect on renal tubular excretion of hydrogen ions.

 

Option C. Hypertension: Correctly associated with Conn's syndrome due to sodium and water retention.

 

Option D. Muscle cramps: Can be associated with hypokalemia seen in Conn's syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Conn's syndrome (primary hyperaldosteronism) is characterized by hypertension, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis. Metabolic acidosis is not a feature of this condition.

questions.text: What is the surgery done to widen the cartilaginous part of the external auditory canal called? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Meatoplasty

 

The surgery done to widen the cartilaginous part of the external auditory canal is meatoplasty.

 

It is performed in combination with all canal wall down procedures like modified radical and radical mastoidectomies, for the treatment of middle ear disease such as cholesteatoma. The widened meats help easily visualize and access the mastoid cavity for periodic inspection and cleaning.

 

It is also done as an isolated procedure in elderly people with sagging auricle. Sagging auricle causes obstruction to the meatus leading to retention of wax and difficulty in hearing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: Tympanoplasty is the surgical reconstruction to correct damage in the middle ear and restore the integrity of the tympanic membrane for improved hearing.

 

Option C: Myringoplasty refers to the reconstruction of the tympanic membrane only.

 

Option D: A cosmetic or reconstructive procedure aimed at correcting deformities or defects of the external part of the ear (pinna).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Meatoplasty is an important surgical option for managing conditions that require improved access to the ear canal and middle ear, particularly in managing chronic ear diseases or anatomical changes that impact ear function.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 32, 457, 463

choices.text: Calcium channel blockers
Alpha methyl dopa

questions.text: A 35-year woman is a chronic hypertensive. She visits the clinic for preconception counseling. Which of the following anti-hypertensives need to be stopped prior to conception? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) ACE inhibitors

 

Explanation:

 

ACE Inhibitors in Pregnancy:

 

  • ACE inhibitors are contraindicated during pregnancy due to their association with significant fetal complications.
  • They can cause oligohydramnios, fetal growth restriction, renal dysgenesis, and even fetal death.
  • Angiotensin Receptor Blockers (ARBs) are also contraindicated for similar reasons.
  • It is essential for women on these medications to discontinue them prior to conception and switch to safer alternatives.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Calcium channel blockers: These are generally considered safe during pregnancy and do not need to be discontinued.

 

Option B. Alpha methyl dopa: This is a safe and commonly used antihypertensive during pregnancy.

 

Option D. Labetalol: Labetalol is another safe option during pregnancy and is frequently used for managing hypertension in pregnant women.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ACE inhibitors and Angiotensin Receptor Blockers are contraindicated during pregnancy and should be discontinued prior to conception.

 

Ref: Page no 401, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition
